title: Be Fearful When Others Are Greedy

sections.summary: This famous maxim by Warren Buffett succinctly captures the essence of contrarian investing. When the crowd is greedy (buying at any price, ignoring risk), the market is overpriced and due for a correction. When the crowd is fearful (selling at any price, ignoring value), the market is underpriced and offers opportunity.
sections.deep_dive: Sentiment is a counter-indicator at extremes. When your taxi driver gives you stock tips, it is time to sell (Greed). When the cover of Time Magazine says 'The Death of Equities', it is time to buy (Fear). The smart money provides liquidity to the emotional money.
sections.council_debate: {"geopolitics": "Crisis Alpha. When war breaks out, the crowd flees (Fear). We buy the dip in high-quality assets that are not directly affected. When peace is declared, the crowd rushes back in (Greed). We sell into the relief rally.", "macro": "Credit Spreads. Tight credit spreads indicate greed (no default fear). Wide spreads indicate fear. sections.forecast_risks: Catching a Falling Knife. Buying fear is dangerous if the fear is justified (e.g., bankruptcy). You must differentiate between 'market panic' (price dislocation) and 'fundamental deterioration' (value destruction). Be greedy only in high-quality assets.
sections.gms_conclusion: You cannot make money doing what everyone else is doing. You must stand apart from the crowd.
